page.title: 03Landscape of Aboyne Area
page.content: {Landscape:} The area is composed of low{hills} (180m) with about one third tree cover. There are both scattered mature deciduous and plantations of pine, also there is much scrub birch on uncultivated land. There are conifer plantations at the Bell Wood 5498 and on Queen's Hill 5200. The {river}Dee flows along the south edge of the area with many meanders and braided islands. The Tarland burn also flows from the north west of the area exiting from the south edge. There are small artificial{Lochs}(Loch of Aboyne and at Rose Hill). To the East of Aboyne Loch the low land is marshy with scrub birch and alongside this the line of the old railway can be seen. There are many scattered farm buildings and the settlement of Aboyne in 5298.
